question:
When using HTTP with persistent connections, a brand-new connection
must be established and maintained for each requested object.
The Domain Name System (DNS) is used to translate hostnames into numerical IP addresses.
An HTTP server is stateless.
Sockets can only be used by an application which uses the TCP protocol as its transport layer protocol.
When streaming stored video through the Internet, we cannot use UDP as the transport layer protocol.
Forward Error Correction (FEC) adds redundant information to a packet stream that can be used to recreate some (potentially) lost information in the network, at the destination.

"Interleaving" can be used by a Voice-over-IP application to mitigate the effect of packet loss. This results in reducing the quality of the received voice signal for a longer time period instead of losing the whole voice signal for a shorter time period.
When streaming stored video, client side buffers can be used to absorb variations in the server-to-client delay.
"Packet jitter" is a result of packet loss in a network.
In symmetric key cryptography, both sender and receiver share a secret key.
In public key cryptography, all keys are public but the algorithm used is secret.
"Message integrity" is the concept of detecting if (or making sure that) the content of a message has (not) been changed.
A "cryptographic hash function" is a special type of checksum to detect unauthorized changes to the content of a message.
A "digital signature" is used to protect against unauthorized access to the content of a message.
In a "known-plaintext" attack, an intruder has access to the encryption process and can get access to the encrypted version (i.e. the ciphertext) corresponding to any chosen plaintext.
"Cipher-Block Chaining" (CBC) is used to make sure that identical blocks of plaintext results in different blocks of ciphertext.
"Secure Sockets Layer" (SSL) is an (application layer) enhancement or extension of TCP to make communication secure.
"IPsec" provides security at the link layer.
A firewall is used to protect an internal network or a single server or PC against attacks via the public Internet.
In a wireless ad hoc network, the mobile units do not communicate via a common access point.
Wireless links are more reliable than wired links (e.g. copper cables, fiber links), thus resulting in fewer bit errors during transmissions.
The "hidden terminal" problem of wireless communication denotes the challenge of synchronizing transmissions to the same frequencies.
An 802.11 wireless LAN use CSMA/CD as medium access protocol.
An 802.11 wireless LAN using an Access Point (AP) is an example of an ad hoc network.
The optional "Request-To-Send" (RTS) / "Clear-To-Send" (CTS) mechanism defined by the 802.11 standard may help solve the hidden terminal problem.
The 4G (LTE) mobile architecture has an all-IP core network.
The 4G (LTE) mobile architecture has a Radio Access Network (RAN) based on CDMA for transmissions over the air.
The 2G (GSM) mobile architecture is a pure circuit-switched network, made mainly for voice conversations.
The "Transmission Control Protocol" (TCP) is the most used transport protocol in the Internet.
The "User Datagram protocol" (UDP) is a connection oriented protocol, well suited for reliable data transfer.
In TCP a "three-way handshake" is used to establish a connection before starting to transfer data.
The "Go-Back-N" (GBN) protocol cannot use cumulative acknowledgements.
Sequence numbers in TCP flow control is based on the number of packets transmitted.
TCP flow control uses cumulative acknowledgements.
"Slow start", "congestion avoidance", and "fast recovery" are all components of the TCP congestion control mechanism.
Sequence numbers in data transmission are used for addressing purposes.
The transport layer is below the network layer in the protocol stack.
Sequence numbers start counting from zero after a new TCP connection is established.

"Routing" is used locally for one router to denote the process of getting a packet from an input link to the (correct) output link; "Forwarding" denotes the whole process of determining a path for a packet from source to destination node, thus involving all network routers.
The Internet Protocol (IP) version 4 uses 48 bit addresses.
The Internet protocol (IP) version 6 uses 128 bit addresses.
Parity bits can be used to detect (and sometimes correct) bit errors in frames sent over a link between two neighboring nodes.
"Cyclic Redundancy Check" (CRC) codes (or polynomial codes) are based on modulo-2 arithmetic without carries in addition or borrows in subtraction.
Shared broadcast medium Ethernets use "Carrier Sense Multiple Access with Collision Detection" (CSMA/CD) as the multiple access protocol.
Switched Ethernets uses "collision-less" (layer 2) store-and-forward frame switches.
Both routers and link-layer switches forward packets or frames based on IP addressing.
The IP version 4 address 223.1.1.0/24 denotes a subnet with a maximum of 28 - 2 = 254 addresses available for local hosts.
The "Internet Control Message Protocol" (ICMP) is used to communicate network layer information between hosts and routers.
